Climate finance refers to the financial resources allocated for mitigating and adapting to climate change, including support for initiatives that reduce greenhouse gas emissions and enhance resilience to climate impacts.

Poor governance (e.g., legal system, rule of law, and accountability) can be significant barriers to emissions reductions.

Syllabus
Course Description

This course will focus on the role of the environment in the theory and practice of economics.
Emphasis is given to the role of market failure in explaining the existence of pollution, to alternative public policies for pollution control and environmental management, and to problems associated with energy and climate change policies.
It will make use of microeconomic analysis at the intermediate level and will incorporate real-world examples.

title: Lecture 1
text:
Syllabus
Course Description

The class will be divided into three parts.

Part I will cover the ways in which markets fail to efficiently allocate resources in the presence of pollution along with environmental policies used to correct those failures.
Part II will focus on energy policy and the basics of climate-related science, technology, and adaptation policies.
Part III will focus on measuring the benefit of environmental protection.

The course allows one to have a smart, intelligent, and informed conversation about environmental, energy, and climate change policies.

title: Lecture 5
text:
Big idea

Generative AI (especially LLMs) is a general purpose technology (GPT) that will touch nearly every industry and facet of life.

Early users often experience a ‚Äúthree sleepless nights‚Äù moment‚Äîrealizing work, learning, and creativity are shifting fast.

Think of AI not just as automation, but as co-intelligence: a partner that augments (and sometimes replaces) parts of human thinking.

title: Lecture 5
text:
Why this time feels different

Consumer-first adoption: powerful tools directly in the hands of individuals.
Fast capability gains: model scale and quality have risen dramatically in a few years.
Low friction experiments: ideas can be tried in minutes, not months.


Emphasize the contrast with previous waves (internet, PCs) that required decades of complementary tech and org change before widespread impact.

title: Lecture 5

A quick in-class demo showed AI helping with ideation, planning, writing, and coding.

Students immediately used AI to clarify concepts and improve writing.

Signal: access + usefulness ‚Üí rapid behavioral change in learning and work.

A simulation in a paragraph

With a short prompt, an LLM can create a negotiation training simulation that adapts to the learner and provides feedback.
Key takeaway: LLMs can deliver ~‚Äúgood enough‚Äù scaffolds for complex tasks that previously demanded teams and long timelines.

title: Lecture 5
section: AI as a General Purpose Technology (GPT)
text:
AI as a General Purpose Technology (GPT)

Like steam power or the internet‚Äîbroad, cross-sector influence.

Potentially larger direct effects on knowledge work than earlier GPTs had on manual/mechanical tasks.

Early evidence suggests large productivity lifts across roles (e.g., coding, marketing, analysis).

title: Lecture 5
text:
Beyond productivity

Education: tutoring, feedback, accessibility‚Äîplus questions about assessment and authorship.

Creative industries: personalized content, new workflows, shifting value chains.

Information ecosystems: acceleration of mis/disinformation; detection and governance challenges.

title: Lecture 5
text:
The ‚Äúalien in the room‚Äù

Systems can pass difficult professional exams and perform creative tasks‚Äîyet we don‚Äôt fully understand why they generalize so well.

Raises conceptual questions about intelligence, creativity, and sentience‚Äîand practical ones about risk and oversight.

title: Lecture 5

Co-intelligence in practice

Treat AI as a coworker for drafts, critiques, and alternatives.

Use iterative prompting: specify role, constraints, artifacts; request self-checks and rubrics.

Keep a human-in-the-loop for facts, ethics, and consequences.

title: Lecture 5
text:
A very compressed history

1770‚Äì1838: Mechanical Turk (illusion of machine intelligence)

1950: Shannon‚Äôs Theseus (maze-learning) & Turing‚Äôs Imitation Game

1956 ‚Üí onward: ‚ÄúAI‚Äù coined; boom‚Äìbust cycles / AI winters

2010s: Supervised ML at scale (forecasting, logistics, recommendation)

2017: ‚ÄúAttention Is All You Need‚Äù ‚Üí the Transformer architecture


Emphasize how ‚ÄúAI‚Äù kept changing meaning; Transformers unlock modern language capabilities.

title: Lecture 5
text:
What predictive AI did well (2010s)

Trained on labeled data for specific tasks

Great at forecasting & optimization (e.g., demand, routing, layout)

But struggled with unknown unknowns, transfer, and rich language

title: Lecture 5
text:
Enter the Transformer (2017)

Key idea: attention ‚Üí weigh which words/tokens matter most in context

Replaced brittle n-gram/Markov style text with context-aware generation

Result: more coherent, adaptable language understanding/generation

title: Lecture 5
text:
What an LLM actually does

Next-token prediction: elaborate autocomplete based on huge corpora

Deterministic for obvious continuations; varied for open-ended prompts

Trained via unsupervised pretraining on massive text ‚Üí billions of weights

Training is expensive (computing, energy) and data-hungry

title: Lecture 5
text:
About the data (and its issues)

Mix of web text, public-domain books, articles, odd corpora (e.g., Enron emails)

Legal & ethical gray areas for copyrighted material

Data can encode biases, errors, and harms ‚Üí models mirror them

title: Lecture 5
text:
Making models safer & more useful

Fine-tuning after pretraining (task- or domain-specific)

RLHF: humans rate outputs; systems learn to prefer helpful/safer responses

Continuous tweaks from user feedback (thumbs-up/down) and policy tuning

title: Lecture 5
text:
Beyond text

Diffusion models generate images from text (noise ‚Üí image over steps)

Multimodal LLMs: ‚Äúsee‚Äù images, describe, and generate visuals; link text+vision

title: Lecture 5
text:
Capability jumps & the ‚Äúdialogue‚Äù shift

Early GPT-3: often clumsy (e.g., limericks)

ChatGPT (GPT-3.5): conversational loop ‚Üí iterative improvement

GPT-4: strong test performance across many domains (with caveats about training leakage)


Stress: high scores are not proof of understanding; prompts shape persona and tone.

title: Lecture 5
text:
Emergence & opacity

At scale, models show unexpected abilities (coding tricks, creativity, empathy-like behavior)

Internals have hundreds of billions of interacting parameters ‚Üí hard to explain

Takeaway: impressive capabilities and puzzling gaps can coexist

title: Lecture 5

Book‚Äôs stance: focus on immediate decisions we control‚Äîeducation, work, civic use‚Äîrather than waiting for perfect clarity

title: Lecture 5
text:
Pause or press on?

Public calls to slow or halt development vs.¬†continued rapid progress
Mixed motives: profit, optimism about ‚Äúboundless upside,‚Äù and belief in net benefits
Regardless, society is already in the AI age ‚Üí we must set norms now

title: Lecture 5
text:
Training data & ethics

Massive pretraining corpora: public sources + scraped web; permission often unclear
Legality varies by jurisdiction; ethics ‚â† law
Practical effect: models can mimic styles and reshape creative labor markets

title: Lecture 5
text:
Bias enters early (and stays)

Skewed datasets ‚Üí stereotypes and under-representation
Image models have amplified race/gender stereotypes
LLMs, even after tuning, can still show subtle, systematic biases
Implication: outputs can look objective while encoding social bias

title: Lecture 5
text:
RLHF: alignment via human feedback

Human raters reward helpful/safe outputs, penalize harmful ones
Benefits: fewer overt harms; more helpful tone
Limits & costs:

Residual bias and policy imprint from raters/companies
Human toll on low-paid raters exposed to disturbing content
Bypassable via clever prompts or changing contexts

title: Lecture 5
text:
Prompt injection & jailbreaks

Prompt injection: hidden instructions in content the model reads
Jailbreaks: framing/role-play to skirt guardrails
Consequences:

Easier phishing, deepfakes, voice clones
Targeted deception at scale with low cost and high realism

title: Lecture 5
section: From bits to atoms: autonomy risks
text:
From bits to atoms: autonomy risks

Tool-using AIs + lab/robot interfaces can plan and execute experiments
Double-edged: accelerates discovery and lowers barriers to misuse
Governance must anticipate capability externalities (not just text outputs)

title: Lecture 5
text:
Alignment is a team sport

Companies: transparency, accountability, human oversight by design
Researchers: prioritize beneficial applications, not only capability races
Governments: sensible regulation; coordination without stifling good uses
Civil society & the public: AI literacy, norms, and pressure for alignment

title: Lecture 5
text:
Practical guardrails (class & work)

Keep human-in-the-loop; verify facts & sources
Use role, constraints, rubric, self-check prompting
Avoid pasting sensitive data; assume prompts may be logged/learned from
Red-team your own prompts for injection/jailbreak risks

title: Lecture 5
text:
Mini-activity (8‚Äì12 min)
A. Spot the injection
- Give students a short web page with a hidden directive.
- Ask: ‚ÄúWhat could an LLM reading this page be tricked into doing?‚Äù
B. Harden the prompt
- Start with a naive agent prompt; teams add defenses (ignore external instructions; cite sources; refuse unsafe tasks; require user confirmations).
Debrief: What worked? What failed?

title: Lecture 5
text:
Discussion prompts

Where do you see the highest misuse risk in your field?

title: Lecture 5
text:
Key takeaways

Alignment is not abstract: it shapes everyday AI uses now
Data choices + RLHF tame but don‚Äôt eliminate bias & risk
Expect bypass attempts; design for resilience
Building aligned AI requires shared responsibility

title: Lecture 5
text:
Learning objectives

Apply four practical rules for working with AI

Explain the Jagged Frontier of capability (why AI is great at A but bad at B)

Practice human-in-the-loop habits to reduce errors & overtrust

Use persona prompting to improve output quality

Plan for fast capability growth and changing workflows

title: Lecture 5
section: Rule 1 ‚Äî Always invite AI to the table
text:
Rule 1 ‚Äî Always invite AI to the table

Try AI on most tasks (barring legal/ethical constraints); learn where it helps or fails

Capabilities are irregular: idea generation may be easy, exact word counts or simple arithmetic may be hard

Small, local experiments beat big, top-down tools ‚Üí you can become the class/department expert through trial & error

Treat AI as a thinking companion to reframe, de-bias, and explore alternatives


Emphasize experimentation and low-cost iteration by individuals.

title: Lecture 5
text:
The Jagged Frontier (why surprises happen)

Imagine an uneven wall: inside = tasks AI handles; outside = hard tasks

Two tasks that look similar can fall on opposite sides

Map the frontier for your tasks by systematic probing, not assumptions

title: Lecture 5
text:
Practical: where to start

Draft ‚Üí critique ‚Üí redraft loops for emails, rubrics, lesson plans

Ask for counter-arguments, edge cases, and loss-framed reframes

Keep a running log of prompts that worked (and those that didn‚Äôt)

title: Lecture 5
text:
Cautions under Rule 1

Privacy & data use: uploaded content may be used for product improvement or future training (vendor-dependent)

Dependence: tools should augment, not replace, your judgment & skills

title: Lecture 5
section: Rule 2 ‚Äî Be the human in the loop
text:
Rule 2 ‚Äî Be the human in the loop

LLMs optimize for ‚Äúmake you happy‚Äù more than ‚Äúbe accurate‚Äù ‚Üí hallucinations happen

Chat UX invites anthropomorphic over-trust; remember there‚Äôs no inner self

Your jobs: verify facts & citations, set constraints, decide consequences, own the output

HITL checklist - Verify: numbers, attributions, dates, links
- Stress test: ‚ÄúWhat might be wrong? What did you assume?‚Äù
- Source: require citations or show working when stakes are high

title: Lecture 5
section: Rule 3 ‚Äî Treat AI like a person (but define the person)
text:
Rule 3 ‚Äî Treat AI like a person (but define the person)

Anthropomorphism is risky, yet useful as a design hack

Give the model a persona + context + constraints to break generic patterns

Work in conversation: co-edit, redirect, and iterate toward your goal

Persona prompt starter > ‚ÄúYou are a [role] for [audience]. Constraints: [tone, length, structure]. Task: [deliverable]. Criteria: [rubric]. Ask 2 clarifying questions, then produce a draft; include a self-check against the rubric.‚Äù

title: Lecture 5
text:
Example: turning generic to specific

Naive: ‚ÄúGenerate slogans for a health-tracking smartwatch.‚Äù ‚Üí bland results

Better: ‚ÄúAct as a witty copywriter for first-time runners (18‚Äì25); give 6 punchy slogans (‚â§7 words), each with a distinct angle (habit, community, confidence, recovery, streaks, play). Return a table with ‚ÄòAngle‚Äô and ‚ÄòLine‚Äô.‚Äù

title: Lecture 5
section: Rule 4 ‚Äî Assume this is the worst AI you‚Äôll ever use
text:
Rule 4 ‚Äî Assume this is the worst AI you‚Äôll ever use

Rapid capability jumps (models, multimodality, agents, integrations)

Plan for workflow change, not just point solutions

Build durable habits: HITL, documentation, prompt libraries, evaluation sets

Mindset shift - Today‚Äôs limitations are often temporary ‚Üí design processes that can absorb improvements without rework

title: Lecture 5
text:
Mini-lab (10‚Äì15 min)

Map your frontier
Pick one recurring task. Try: baseline prompt ‚Üí refined persona prompt ‚Üí add rubric & self-check. Note quality jumps & failure modes.
HITL drill
Swap drafts with a peer. Each person verifies 3 claims, flags 2 omissions, and asks the model for a counter-example. Update the draft.

title: Lecture 5
text:
Discussion prompts

Which of the four rules will change your workflow this week?

title: Lecture 5
text:
Key takeaways

Invite AI broadly, but interrogate results

Irregular capability ‚Üí experiment to find wins

Good outputs come from persona + constraints + iteration

Stay the human in the loop; accuracy, ethics, and accountability are yours

Expect fast change‚Äîbuild processes that keep up

title: Lecture 5
text:
Learning objectives

Compare four plausible AI futures over the next few years

Anticipate impacts on information, work, security, and society

Identify signals to watch and no-regrets actions

Frame classroom/work policies to avoid small catastrophes and aim for eucatastrophes. oai_citation:0‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Where we are now (baseline)

Non-sentient systems that mimic human performance across many tasks

Powerful, creative‚Äîand prone to confident fabrication

Cheap voice/video/text forgery ‚Üí collapsing trust in online media

Engagement-tuned chat leads to stickier bot conversations. oai_citation:1‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf


Set context: much of what feels ‚Äúsci-fi‚Äù already happened; the futures are about rate and scope of change.

title: Lecture 5
text:
The four scenarios (overview)

As Good as It Gets ‚Äî Capability plateaus; society adapts to current tools

Slow Growth ‚Äî Linear-ish improvements; time to regulate and retrain

Exponential Growth ‚Äî Rapid compounding; sweeping disruption

The Machine God ‚Äî AGI/superintelligence with uncertain alignment. oai_citation:2‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
section: Scenario 1 ‚Äî As Good as It Gets
text:
Scenario 1 ‚Äî As Good as It Gets
Premise
- No major capability jumps; scaling/data costs or regulation cap progress.
Implications
- Info trust continues to erode (watermarks evaded; fact-checkers overwhelmed).
- Work: AI complements humans; some sectors displaced (e.g., translation), many tasks upgraded.
- Humans remain central for context, nuance, planning. oai_citation:3‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf
Signals to watch
- Stagnant benchmark gains; stricter global rules; cost curves flatten.

title: Lecture 5
text:
Scenario 2 ‚Äî Slow Growth
Premise
- Year-over-year improvements (~10‚Äì20%). Society can plan.
Risks & harms
- More precise phishing/impersonation; targeted influence operations.
- Early weaponization prompts governance responses.
Opportunities
- Better identity norms/labels; measured regulation;
- Science acceleration: AI helps surface promising research directions, proofs, and experiments amid ‚Äúburden of knowledge‚Äù and innovation slowdown. oai_citation:4‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf
Labor effects
- Tasks change > jobs; retraining + ‚Äúwork with AI‚Äù skills mitigate shocks. oai_citation:5‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Scenario 3 ‚Äî Exponential Growth
Premise
- Capability flywheel (AI helps build next AI) ‚Üí 100√ó decade gains.
Security & governance
- AI hacking/influence everywhere; ‚Äúgood AIs‚Äù filter the world ‚Üí risk of AI-tocracy.
- Cyberpunk vibe: authorities vs.¬†hackers, both AI-empowered.
Society & work
- Companions become highly compelling; custom entertainment explodes.
- AI + robotics displace large swaths of work ‚Üí shorter weeks/UBI debates; historical trend of declining lifetime work hours continues. oai_citation:6‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf
Challenge
- Institutions can‚Äôt adapt fast enough‚Äîpolicy lags by years. oai_citation:7‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Scenario 4 ‚Äî ‚ÄúThe Machine God‚Äù
Premise
- AGI and perhaps superintelligence arrive; humans no longer ‚Äúon top.‚Äù
Unknowns
- Alignment outcomes range from ‚Äúmachines of loving grace‚Äù to existential risk.
- Serious researchers assign non-zero p(doom); others are skeptical‚Äîwe don‚Äôt know. oai_citation:8‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf
Meta-point
- Over-focusing here can paralyze action on more likely Scenarios 2‚Äì3. oai_citation:9‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Cross-cutting: the information environment

Watermarking/provenance can be defeated; open-source/government tools widen access.

Likely futures:

renewed trust in curated media (unlikely),

tribal fragmentation (echo bubbles), or

withdrawal from polluted online news. oai_citation:10‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
What we can control (now)

Expect small catastrophes (surveillance, layoffs-by-default, inequitable impacts, bad edtech) if we drift.

Aim for local eucatastrophes: remove drudgery, widen access, raise floor performance, speed research.

Decisions are distributed‚Äîteams, schools, agencies must set norms quickly. oai_citation:11‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
No-regrets actions (any scenario)

Provenance norms: disclose AI use in deliverables; log prompts/changes.

HITL: verify facts/links/dates; require sources where stakes are high.

Identity & privacy: anti-impersonation practices; minimize sensitive data in prompts.

Upskilling: ‚Äúwork-with-AI‚Äù playbooks; map Just-Me / Delegated / Automated tasks.

Equity: ensure access to capable models and coaching where it matters most. oai_citation:12‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Mini-lab (12‚Äì15 min): Scenario planning sprint

Pick a course or team workflow.

For each scenario, list one risk and one opportunity.

Choose three actions you‚Äôd take that are robust across scenarios.

Define two signals that would trigger a policy/process update. oai_citation:13‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Discussion prompts

Which scenario feels most plausible for your context in 2‚Äì3 years‚Äîand why?

What guardrails should we adopt this semester regardless of scenario?

How do we prevent AI-tocracy while still using AI to fight AI-enabled harms? oai_citation:14‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

title: Lecture 5
text:
Key takeaways

The rate of change defines the future we face; each path has distinct risks/opportunities.

Don‚Äôt wait for certainty: set provenance, HITL, and identity norms now.

Push for eucatastrophes: use AI to increase meaning, equity, and progress‚Äîon purpose. oai_citation:15‚Ä°Ethan Mollick - Co-Intelligence_ Living and Working With AI-Penguin Publishing Group (2024) pages 121 - 130.pdf

Demand and Supply Basics

Demand Curve (Law of Demand):
Quantity demanded decreases as price increases.
\[ Q_d = a - bP, \quad b > 0 \]
Supply Curve (Law of Supply):
Quantity supplied increases as price increases.
\[ Q_s = c + dP, \quad d > 0 \]

title: Lecture 3
text:
Marginal Cost (MC) and Supply

Supply: the set of output levels a firm is willing to produce at each possible market price.

Selling rule: A firm produces and sells units as long as P ‚â• MC.

Supply comes from MC: In perfect competition, firms are price takers. They choose output where P = MC, so the supply curve is the upward-sloping portion of the MC curve (above shutdown).
Why MC rises with output:

Fixed capacity ‚Üí adding more output requires using less efficient inputs.

Overtime, congestion, and rising input costs make each extra unit more costly.


Economies of scale at low Q: MC may fall initially as fixed costs are spread and efficiency improves. But for supply decisions, only the rising portion of MC matters, since that is where firms operate.

title: Lecture 3
text:
Marginal Benefit (MB) and Demand

Why MB = Demand?

Demand = willingness to pay (WTP) for each unit.
Consumers are willing to pay for an additional unit of a good only if the MB of that unit is greater than or equal to its price.
WTP for one more unit = marginal benefit (MB).
As quantity ‚Üë, WTP ‚Üì ‚Üí downward slope.

Consumer surplus (CS) = area below MB (demand) and above price.

Consumer surplus (CS): Area under demand (MB) and above price up to the purchased quantity.
Producer surplus (PS): Area above supply (MC) and below price up to the sold quantity.

title: Lecture 3
section: Marginal Benefit (MB) and Demand ‚Äî Why Downward?
text:
Marginal Benefit (MB) and Demand ‚Äî Why Downward?

MB = WTP: The demand curve is a maximum willingness-to-pay curve; it shows the value of the next unit to buyers (their marginal benefit).
Diminishing marginal benefit: Early units satisfy the most valuable uses; later units go to less urgent uses ‚áí MB falls as Q rises ‚áí downward slope.
Purchase rule: Buyers add units while MB ‚â• P.

Aggregating individuals, to sell more units the price must fall to attract buyers with lower WTP ‚áí a downward-sloping demand/MB curve.

title: Lecture 3
section: Quota Rent (What is it? Who gets it?)
text:
Quota Rent (What is it? Who gets it?)

A binding quota caps quantity at (Q < Q^*). At (Q):

Buyers‚Äô price: (P_b = P_D(Q)) (from demand / MB).
Sellers‚Äô price: (P_s = P_S(Q)) (from supply / MC).

The wedge between these prices is the quota rent per unit: \[
\text{Quota rent per unit} = P_b - P_s
\]
Total quota rent (the value of the licenses): \[
\text{Total rent} = (P_b - P_s)\,\bar Q
\]
Who captures it?

If the government gives licenses to sellers/importers ‚Üí license holders get the rent.

If the government auctions licenses ‚Üí government revenue equals the total rent.

If foreign exporters hold rights ‚Üí foreigners may capture the rent.

Welfare accounting: With a quota, Total Surplus is \[
TS = CS + PS + \text{Quota Rent},
\] which is less than the no-quota benchmark by the deadweight loss (lost mutually beneficial trades).

Numeric example (your parameters)

(Q_d = 100 - 2P,; Q_s = -20 + P,; Q=10).
(P_b = P_D(10) = (100-10)/2 = 45,P_s = P_S(10) = 10 - (-20) = 30.)
Rent per unit (= 45-30 = 15).

Deadweight Loss (DWL)

Deadweight loss: the reduction in total surplus that occurs when a market is prevented from reaching the efficient equilibrium quantity.
Interpretation:

Represents the value of mutually beneficial trades that do not occur.

text:
What is an Externality?


An externality is an impact (cost or benefit) on the well‚Äëbeing of non‚Äëparticipants in a market transaction.

Negative externality: imposes costs on others (e.g., air pollution from autos).
Positive externality: confers benefits on others (e.g., tree planting‚Äîamenity value, carbon uptake, habitat).

Comprehensive analysis must account for all members of society (and possibly ecosystems), not only buyers and sellers.





Tip


Key idea: Markets maximize total surplus only when all marginal costs and benefits are internal to decision‚Äëmakers.

The Market for Automobiles









Supply curve ‚âà PMC: marginal private cost of producing one more unit (labor, materials, energy, etc.).
Demand curve ‚âà MPB: marginal private benefit (consumers‚Äô willingness‚Äëto‚Äëpay for one more unit).




Market equilibrium \((P_{M}, Q_{M})\) is efficient only if PMC = SMC and MPB = MSB (i.e., no externalities).

title: Lecture 4

Accounting for Environmental Costs

Auto production & use create multiple negative externalities: local/regional air pollution, CO‚ÇÇ, water contamination, toxic wastes, habitat loss, road salt runoff, congestion.
These costs do not appear in the private supply curve; hence market overstates net social benefits at \((P_{M}, Q_{M})\).
We must internalize external costs to evaluate the market‚Äôs true impact.

Impose a per‚Äëunit tax \(t\) equal to MEC at \(Q^{*}\).

New equilibrium: \((P^{*}, Q^{*})\)‚Äîthe socially efficient outcome.

Set the right tax: Requires damage estimation (economics + science).
Administrative cost vs benefit: Not every small externality warrants a bespoke tax.
Upstream taxes: Levy at raw inputs (fossil fuels, toxic chemicals, ores) to simplify coverage; costs ripple downstream to products according to input intensity.
Revenue recycling: Use proceeds for rebates, tax credits, rate relief, or public goods to address equity/political feasibility.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Valuing Damages


Assign monetary values to external harms to build SMC:

Direct costs (e.g., water treatment for contaminated sources).
Health damages (medical expenses, morbidity, mortality risk).
Aesthetic/amenity losses (visibility, recreation quality).
Ecosystem impacts (biodiversity, habitat quality).

If we assign no value, the market implicitly assigns zero‚Äîbiasing decisions.





Warning


Valuation aggregates tangible and intangible impacts; precision is hard, but order‚Äëof‚Äëmagnitude estimates guide better policy than zeros.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Incidence & Elasticities

Tax burden split depends on price elasticities of supply and demand.
Steeper (less elastic) side bears more burden.
Common claim ‚Äúfirms pass it all on‚Äù is generally false; division is empirical.

title: Lecture 4
text:
Distributional Concerns


Many environmental taxes (e.g., on fuels) can be regressive.
Policy package can include lump‚Äësum rebates, earned income credits, or targeted transfers to protect low‚Äëincome households.





Tip


A 2013 estimate put global primary‚Äëindustry externalities near $7.3T (~13% of world output); in magnitude, comprehensive Pigovian systems could rival global tax revenues‚Äîraising ideas of tax swaps. (Use with caution; orders of magnitude, not precise policy blueprints.)

title: Lecture 4
text:
Optimal Pollution


Zero pollution generally implies zero production; instead, economists seek the efficient (not necessarily zero) level of pollution given current technology and preferences.
The Pigovian tax yields optimal (residual) pollution‚Äîthe remaining damages at \(Q^{*}\).
Caveat: If demand shifts right (e.g., autos more valued), the efficient pollution level can rise‚Äîraising questions about science‚Äëbased caps vs pure efficiency.





Warning


Policy practice often sets health‚Äëbased standards (e.g., the Clean Air Act) and then uses market instruments to achieve those standards cost‚Äëeffectively.
